courses.name: Art and Ideas

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history of art, architecture and allied arts. This introduction to the history of art will examine a wide range of objects, selected and discussed in connection with a special theme to be selected by the instructor. Students will be expected to study the history and significance of art through the close reading of selected texts that relate to both art and theory. Special attention will be given to developing essential art historical skills necessary for upper level courses. The topic for each semester will vary based on the instructor. No previous knowledge of history of art or architecture is required. Frequent writing assignments and exercises will be based on readings, lectures, and museum or gallery visits to collections in Toronto.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Ideas

courses.name: Art and Ideas

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of the history of art, architecture and allied arts. This introduction to the history of art will examine a wide range of objects, selected and discussed in connection with a special theme to be selected by the instructor. Students will be expected to study the history and significance of art through the close reading of selected texts that relate to both art and theory. Special attention will be given to developing essential art historical skills necessary for upper level courses. The topic for each semester will vary based on the instructor. No previous knowledge of history of art or architecture is required. Frequent writing assignments and exercises will be based on readings, lectures, and museum or gallery visits to collections in Toronto.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Ideas

courses.name: On Foot: From Pilgrimage to the Mobile City

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: August 6, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: Walking is a basic human activity, yet it also defines and shapes us. In order to understand the permutations of this seemingly simple activity we will look at walking in a variety of contexts through the study of texts, art, movies and the built environment. Restricted to first-year students. Not available for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: On Foot: From Pilgrimage to the Mobile City

courses.name: Marco Polo's World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the visual and material worlds of the Italian traveller Marco Polo, which are described in his Travels. Together we will read sections of this text and explore their meaning with respect to the objects and monuments of Marco Polo’s time from the regions to which he travelled. By studying cartography, art, architecture, and urban form in the expansive medieval world of Marco Polo, the course will introduce us to the global world of the Middle Ages. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Marco Polo's World

courses.name: Classical Art from Greek Gods to Roman Gladiators

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: January 13, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: The ancient Greeks and Romans lived in a world full of images. Ancient visual culture comprises not only the high arts but also the everyday. This course is meant to introduce students to key ideas about how art and images in general impacted the life of ancient Greeks and Romans. Students will learn to examine various categories of visual material ranging from the pictorial and applied arts (painting, sculpture, architecture) to everyday artifacts (for example, domestic wares, jewelry or weapons). Through a series of discussion-centred seminar sessions students will explore the interconnections between art and ideology, art and identity as well as visuality and viewing. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Classical Art from Greek Gods to Roman Gladiators

courses.name: Shocking Artists, Shocking Art

cmCourseInfo.description: Art causes scandals for many reasons, provoking a range of consequences, including censorship, cuts to government funding of the arts or even destruction of the work in question. In this course we will consider a number of kinds of art scandal arising from exhibition in public galleries and urban spaces, including those that have to do with legal issues such as plagiarism and vandalism; aesthetic objections on the part of the public, ranging from perceived obscenity to simple resentment of abstract art; racism; sacrilege; and political subversion, amongst others. We will consider the work of artists including Chris Ofili, Joep van Lieshout, Paul McCarthy, Damien Hirst, Michael Snow, Sally Mann, Banksy, Rachel Whiteread, Richard Prince, Andres Serrano, Robert Mapplethorpe, Carl Andre, Maya Lin, and Jeff Koons, amongst others. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Shocking Artists, Shocking Art

courses.name: Greek and Roman Art and Archaeology

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of the major monuments, artifacts, themes and problems in the study of the archaeology, art and architecture of the civilizations of Greece and Rome.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek and Roman Art and Archaeology

courses.name: Early Medieval Art and Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of major monuments and themes in the art and architecture of Western Europe and the Byzantine East from the third until the eleventh century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Early Medieval Art and Architecture

courses.name: Renaissance Art and Architecture

cmCourseInfo.description: A selective survey of the major art centres and types of artistic and architectural production in Italy and northern Europe, from the early fifteenth century to the mid-sixteenth. Themes include the relations--artistic, economic and ideological--between northern and southern Europe during this period, the changing role of art in religious life, the emergence of secular themes, and the legacies left by Renaissance art to modern life and culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Renaissance Art and Architecture

courses.name: Baroque Art and Architecture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: December 16, 2019.

cmCourseInfo.description: Major forms of expression in the visual arts ca. 1600 - ca. 1750 with particular attention to forms, techniques, theories, and patronage of the arts as well as biographies of artists in Italy, France, the Netherlands, Flanders, Germany and England.
cmCourseInfo.title: Baroque Art and Architecture

courses.name: Modernism and anti-Modernism, c. 1750-1900

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the advent and development of art movements including Rococo and Neoclassicism; Romanticism and Revolution, Realism and the advent of Photography, Impressionism; Academic art; Post-Impressionism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modernism and anti-Modernism, c. 1750-1900

courses.name: Art and Visual Experience in Modern and Contemporary East Asia

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: New Course Added: June 24, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: An overview of major monuments and themes in the art and architecture of East Asia (China, Japan, Korea, Vietnam, Mongolia and Tibet) and its diaspora in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Visual Experience in Modern and Contemporary East Asia

courses.name: Monuments of the Islamic World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the architecture of the Islamic world from the 7th - 12th centuries through the lens of its major monuments throughout the central Islamic lands, North Africa and Spain. Through an emphasis upon the Umayyad, Abbasid, Fatimid and Seljuk periods, the course explores the range of cultural, political, social and religious aspects related to the development of the built environment. It also considers the impact of Islam's encounter with late antiquity and aims to position the rise of Islamic architecture within the context of this encounter. Additionally, the architecture is contextualized through a study of the urban history of select early and medieval Islamic cities.
cmCourseInfo.title: Monuments of the Islamic World

courses.name: Architecture: Rituals and Monuments

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of architecture from pre-history to the start of modernism, with attention given to the ways in which architecture shapes human experience.
cmCourseInfo.title: Architecture: Rituals and Monuments

courses.name: Modern Architecture from 1750 to the Present

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: September 18, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to the buildings, issues and ideas from Neoclassicism to the present.
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Architecture from 1750 to the Present

courses.name: City of Rome

cmCourseInfo.description: The art, architecture and archaeology of the city of Rome to AD476.
cmCourseInfo.title: City of Rome

courses.name: Greek Sculpture

cmCourseInfo.description: The course provides a thorough examination of ancient Greek sculpture from 7th - 1st century BCE, which in many ways defined the canon of western art that was to follow. Classic issues of style, dating, and technique are complemented by putting them into the contexts of cultural history, religion and socio-politics. While the course is a traditional monument-based survey of major sculptural works from the ancient Greek world, several important issues are also addressed, pertaining both to contemporary society and the study of other areas of art history. These include but are not limited to: gender, social class, colonialism, notion of the artist, originality, and aesthetic theory.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek Sculpture

courses.name: Greek Myth in Ancient Art

cmCourseInfo.description: A general introduction to Greek mythology and its uses (and abuses) by the Greeks and Romans through the art of antiquity. Students will learn about gods and goddesses, heroes and heroines, their attributes and stories which constituted the subjects of (not only) ancient art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Greek Myth in Ancient Art

courses.name: Cultural History of Islamic Spain

cmCourseInfo.description: From its earliest beginnings as an Umayyad province and up until the 15th century, al-Andalus acted as a lynch pin within the Mediterranean world. Connecting the Islamic empire in the East and forging links of trade and cultural exchange with Europe to the West, cities such as Cordoba and Granada captured the imagination of contemporary chroniclers, earning descriptions in the sources as truly “first-rate places”. Through an exploration of the historical, artistic, architectural, urban, social and economic contexts, this course will engage with and expand upon current understandings of this seminal period in Islamic history to examine Islam’s encounters and modes of cultural exchange with Europe and the Mediterranean world.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cultural History of Islamic Spain
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any Medieval 200 or 300 level half-course (any one of FAH215H1, FAH216H1, FAH318H1, FAH319H1, FAH327H1, or FAH328H1).

courses.name: German Art and Architecture in the Age of Dürer

cmCourseInfo.description: Albrecht Dürer and the painting and printmaking of his contemporaries. Consideration of the great Hall churches of Saxony and the altarpieces of Tilman Riemenschneider and his contemporaries; the status of the arts and attitudes towards Italian art, and the consequences of the Reformation for religious imagery.
cmCourseInfo.title: German Art and Architecture in the Age of Dürer

courses.name: Art and Consumers in the Renaissance (1400-1700)

cmCourseInfo.description: It has long been said that the material culture of the Renaissance generated the first stir of consumerism with a variety of artifacts produced from 1400 to 1700 in Italy.  This course explores the material culture of Renaissance consumerism and discusses the production and function of works in different art media.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art and Consumers in the Renaissance (1400-1700)

courses.name: 17th-Century Art of the Netherlands

cmCourseInfo.description: Concentration on the major painters of Holland’s Golden Age, ca. 1580-ca. - 1700. Particular attention is paid to genre painting and the notion of “Dutch realism.” Consideration of art within its social and political contexts. Notions of gender, of the historical past, of embodiment, and of contact with the non-western world will be discussed.
cmCourseInfo.title: 17th-Century Art of the Netherlands

courses.name: Cubism and Related Movements

cmCourseInfo.description: An investigation of the birth and development of Cubism, Futurism and Orphism in Europe and North America.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cubism and Related Movements

courses.name: The Dada and Surrealist Tradition

cmCourseInfo.description: The origins and development of the Dada and Surrealist movements in early 20th-century Western art, and their lasting impact on art after World War II. Painting, sculpture, graphic arts, and the theoretical preoccupation which accompanied artistic production.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Dada and Surrealist Tradition

courses.name: On Display: Cultures of Exhibition, 1789-1900

cmCourseInfo.description: Examination of the historical development of the cultures of exhibition in Nineteenth-Century Europe, and the diversity of venues displaying works of art and nature. Historical and theoretical overview is complemented by case studies which include investigations of private cabinets of curiosity, encyclopedic museums, commercial galleries, side-shows, and world's fairs.
cmCourseInfo.title: On Display: Cultures of Exhibition, 1789-1900
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: some introduction to art and/or cultural history

courses.name: The Mechanics of the Image in China

cmCourseInfo.description: East Asian images differ from Western ones in material support, format, and technologies of image-making. This course probes how East Asian images -- painting on objects, handscrolls, prints, optical media, film, and new media – work.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Mechanics of the Image in China
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 200 level FAH half course/ANY 100 or 200 level EAS Society-Culture course

courses.name: European Renaissance Architecture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: New Course Added: June 24, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: Architecture and architectural theory ca. 1400 – ca. 1600.
cmCourseInfo.title: European Renaissance Architecture

courses.name: Special Topics in Art History

cmCourseInfo.description: The study of various aesthetic, cultural, social, political, and theoretical aspects of Western art and photography across the centuries.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Art History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Two FAH half courses or permission of instructor

courses.name: Problems in Jewish Art

cmCourseInfo.description: This course investigates the changing definition of Jewish art and the status of Jewish artists. Other issues explored include Jewish-Christian visual polemics, the construction of individual and communal Jewish identity through art, architecture, and texts, and the conceptual transformation of Jewish craft and ritual objects into art.
cmCourseInfo.title: Problems in Jewish Art
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: FAH102H1, a 200 level FAH half course

courses.name: Art Writing

cmCourseInfo.description: Study and practice in the variety of writing genres and styles associated with art history and contemporary criticism. Students will develop skills in writing for museum exhibitions and publications, reviews and criticism, academic analysis, and writing for popular print and media. Regular and frequent writing assignments. Recommended for FAH majors and specialists.
cmCourseInfo.title: Art Writing

courses.name: Aegean Wall Paintings

cmCourseInfo.description: Investigation of the wall-paintings of the Minoan, Cycladic and Mycenaean worlds in the second millennium BC: context, associations, viewing and historical interpretations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Aegean Wall Paintings

courses.name: Studies in Roman Painting and Sculpture

cmCourseInfo.description: Issues explored might cover Republican and Imperial painting; its Hellenistic sources and parallel media (mosaic, relief). The four distinctive genres of Roman sculptural production: the portrait, the historical relief, sarcophagi, and replicas of famous Greek sculptures. Styles, themes and modes of display in cultural context.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Roman Painting and Sculpture

courses.name: Studies in Western Medieval Art and Architecture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: November 20, 2019.

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth examination of monuments and issues in the art and architecture of Western Europe from the sixth to the fifteenth century.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Western Medieval Art and Architecture

courses.name: Studies in Medieval Cities

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: September 11, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: A focused examination of urbanism, art and architecture of a specific medieval city, such as Jerusalem, Rome, Constantinople, or Paris.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Medieval Cities

courses.name: The First Art Historians

cmCourseInfo.description: In Vasari’s Lives of the Artists and their “after-lives,” painters and humanists explored questions of word and image, art and life, biography and history, the psychology of style, the economics and politics of art and the languages of art. How and why did art history originate?
cmCourseInfo.title: The First Art Historians

courses.name: Italian Renaissance Art, Fashion, and Material Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar explores fashion in the visual and material culture of Renaissance Italy. It focuses on the discourse of fashion as represented by Renaissance artists in their works and as treated in contemporary texts. It further examines the multiple meanings of dress in the courts of Renaissance Italy.
cmCourseInfo.title: Italian Renaissance Art, Fashion, and Material Culture

courses.name: Dutch Genre Painting of the 17th Century

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: November 20, 2019.

cmCourseInfo.description: Study of so-called “scenes of everyday life.” Special attention given to cultural context and problems of constructions of gender and gendered relationships, of social and economic interests, of class conflict, of the relationship with broader European culture. Considerable attention will be paid to the work of Jan Vermeer.
cmCourseInfo.title: Dutch Genre Painting of the 17th Century
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Reading knowledge of French or German

courses.name: 19th-Century Landscape Painting

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Changed: September 5, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: Investigation of English, French, German and Swiss landscape painting from the birth of the Romantic movement to Post-Impressionism.
cmCourseInfo.title: 19th-Century Landscape Painting
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Reading knowledge of French or German

courses.name: Contemporary Art Movements

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Birds, Balloons and Drones: The Aerial Image in Photography

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: New Course Added: July 9, 2019

sections.name: LEC0201
sections.subTitle: Digital Art and the Politics of Immersive Media

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
New Course Added: July 9, 2019.
Room Changed: November 20, 2019.

cmCourseInfo.description: Selected aspects of the complex array of international contemporary art movements, their artists, objects, and critical discourses. Potential issues include the theoretical, philosophical, and political concerns addressed by given artworks and artists; the role of art journals, the private patron, and museum display.
cmCourseInfo.title: Contemporary Art Movements

courses.name: Exhibiting China

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Room Change: January 23, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: This seminar teaches students the skills required to curate an exhibition of Chinese materials. Working firsthand with objects of Chinese art and visual culture in local Toronto collections, students learn to document the object, assess authenticity, write object labels, panel texts, and catalogue essays. Students will thus prepare an exhibition, actual or virtual, of Chinese objects in local collections.
cmCourseInfo.title: Exhibiting China
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: FAH260H1/ FAH262H1/ FAH360H1/ FAH363H1/ FAH364H1/ FAH368H1/ EAS211Y0/ EAS227Y/ EAS233H1/ EAS237Y1/ EAS305Y1/ EAS331Y1; permission of instructor
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: Two additional courses in Chinese/East Asian art

courses.name: Studies in Canadian Architecture and Landscapes

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth study of themes in the history of architecture and landscape in Canada.
cmCourseInfo.title: Studies in Canadian Architecture and Landscapes

courses.name: Internship

cmCourseInfo.description: The internship is designed to offer hands-on experience pertaining to the study, exhibition, and care of works of art, focused on the collections and activities of the University Art Centre, an auction house, a public museum, or a private gallery. Students must provide proof of their acceptance as an intern by the Art Centre/auction house/museum/gallery in order to be enrolled in the course. This course is Pass/Fail. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Internship
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor (application in department)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
To enrol in this course, please contact contact Louise Kermode at the Art Department for details, email undergrad.arthistory@utoronto.ca.

courses.name: Introduction to Conservation: Materials, Deterioration, and Preservation in Art and Material Culture

cmCourseInfo.description: An introduction to conservation, designed to give students a basic understanding of the field, its techniques, and its purposes. Sessions conducted by specialists in the Royal Ontario Museum conservation department.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Conservation: Materials, Deterioration, and Preservation in Art and Material Culture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor.

courses.name: Fashion, & Textiles: Culture & Consumption

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the history, meaning and consumption of Western European textiles (Late Antique - 18th century) and fashionable dress (18th - 21st centuries). Analysis and research will combine student seminars with the study of actual artefacts in the Textile & Costume Collection of the Royal Ontario Museum.
cmCourseInfo.title: Fashion, & Textiles: Culture & Consumption

courses.name: Collecting Canada: Canadian Pictorial Arts Collection at the Royal Ontario Museum

cmCourseInfo.description: Theoretical and practical engagement with the ROM's Canadian paintings, prints and drawing collections (18th-20th C). Through lectures, workshops, and seminars, we consider the collecting, interpretation, and display of images within the framework of “documentary art” and its various connotations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Collecting Canada: Canadian Pictorial Arts Collection at the Royal Ontario Museum

courses.name: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Time Changed: June 3, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth investigation of objects at the Royal Ontario Museum. Content will vary according to the museum department offering the course in any given semester.
cmCourseInfo.title: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

courses.name: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Exhibiting Islamic Art and Material Culture

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: New Course Added: July 9, 2019

cmCourseInfo.description: In-depth investigation of objects at the Royal Ontario Museum. Content will vary according to the museum department offering the course in any given semester.
cmCourseInfo.title: Case Studies at the Royal Ontario Museum

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
After enrolling on ACORN and to complete enrolment in this course, students must submit the FAH486 enrolment approval form found here: https://art.utoronto.ca/undergraduates/courses/

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content:
New Course Added: July 9, 2019.
Room Changed: November 20, 2019.

cmCourseInfo.description: Focused examination of special topics in any period of Mediterranean, European, North American, or Asian art and architecture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in the History of Art and Architecture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8 FAH half courses; permission of instructor
